Research paper Effects of rare-earth (Nd, Er and Y) doping on catalytic performance of HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts for methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) decomposition Dedong He a Husheng Hao a Dingkai Chen a Jiangping Liu a Jie Yu a Jichang Lu a Feng Liu a Sufang He b Kongzhai Li c Yongming Luo a ⁎ a Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650500, PR China Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650500 PR China b Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, PR China Research Center for Analysis and Measurement Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650093 PR China c State Key Laboratory of Complex Nonferrous Metal Resources Clean Utilization, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, PR China State Key Laboratory of Complex Nonferrous Metal Resources Clean Utilization Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650093 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts modified with various rare earth metals (Nd, Er and Y) was prepared and used for CH3SH catalytic decomposition test. The results revealed that addition of rare earth metals significantly improved activity and stability of the HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts, and Nd-modified catalyst exhibited the best performance. Several characterization studies were undertaken to correlate structural and surface properties of the obtained catalysts with their catalytic performance. It was found that acid-base properties of the catalysts were closely related to the catalytic performance. The NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analysis showed that the concentration of strong acid sites of the HZSM-5 catalysts decreased after rare earth metals addition, while the concentration of basic sites of the catalysts increased. The decrease in the amount of strong acid sites suppressed the formation of coke on the catalysts. The catalysts with increased amount of basic sites displayed better adsorption ability to CH3SH. The UV–vis, 27Al NMR and XRD analysis indicated that the existence of an empty f orbit Nd3+ caused the increase of non-framework aluminium species amount, which leaded to the decrease of the strong acid sites amount. In addition, the optimal loading amount of Nd was investigated and 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst showed no obvious deactivation during 60h test. The spent Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst can be successfully regenerated, showing that Nd/HZSM-5 was an efficient catalyst for CH3SH elimination. Keywords CH3SH decomposition Rare earth Activity and stability Acid-base properties Nd content 1 Introduction Nowadays, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which are causing serious health and environmental problems, have been required to be strictly controlled all around the world [1]. Methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) is a model sulfur-containing volatile organic pollutant that is generated from various industrial sources (e.g. petroleum refining processes, wood-pulping industries, DL-methionine manufacturing processes and some environmental pollution-control activities) and easily detected in ambient air (the olfactory threshold of CH3SH is as low as 0.002ppm) [2,3]. Moreover, CH3SH is also regarded as a source that will cause catalysts to be deactivated and poisoned during many catalytic reactions (such as the reactions in synthesis of methanol and ammonia) [4]. Therefore, the raised environmental awareness and the increased catalytic technical standards have urgently stimulated the importance to find a suitable method to control the emission of CH3SH. Diverse technologies have been developed to removal this odorous gas (CH3SH), including alkaline treatment [5], biological degradation [6], absorption [7] and catalytic oxidation [8]. But catalytic decomposition method may provide an alternative to other methods, since it requires no additional reagents and produces very small amount of waste during the degradation process, which has been predominantly performed recently [9–15]. Among all the catalysts studied, much more attention has been paid to HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst, which is considered as a good candidate for CH3SH catalytic decomposition [13–15]. These studies have shown that CH3SH can be completely decomposed into hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and some inorganic hydrocarbons (e.g. CH4, C2H6, C2H4, etc.) above 550°C [13–15]. Since the produced H2S can be easily captured by amine extraction process or commercially converted to elemental sulfur from Claus technique. Therefore, this chemical transformation may be regarded as a tempting process for achieving the completely removal of CH3SH in further researches. However, the stability of the pure HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst in some reaction processes is not satisfactory, and seriously deactivation of the catalyst is observed because of its strong acidity, as the presence of strong acid sites usually promote the formation of coke deposit [16,17]. During CH3SH catalytic decomposition test, pure HZSM-5 catalyst with high CH3SH conversion rapidly deactivate after about 15h time on stream [13,14]. In fact, ceria based catalysts investigated in our previous researches also face with the problem that catalysts will deactivate after about 10h test [10–12]. Therefore, it is essential to make efforts to increase the stability of the pure HZSM-5 catalyst. It has been reported that the formation of coke deposit can be reduced and the stability of zeolite catalysts can be enhanced by means of adding some rare earth metals (e.g. La, Ce) [18,19]. Broadly speaking, acid-base properties of the zeolite catalysts could be effectively tuned by modifying these catalysts with small amounts of rare earth oxides which have strong basic character [20]. However, to our best knowledge, there has been no report on rare earth metals (e.g. Nd, Er and Y. Nd are considered as the light rare earth element, and Er and Y are classified as the heavy rare earth elements) modified HZSM-5 for CH3SH catalytic decomposition so far, which initiates us to study this catalytic reaction system. Additionally, it has been well known that the dual properties of both acidity and alkalinity of zeolite catalysts can play a vital role in many catalytic processes [21]. The acidic properties of the zeolite catalysts have been investigated, while their basic properties have rarely been focused on. It is believed that the presence of increased concentration of basic sites on the catalysts will has a positive effect on their catalytic performance, since CH3SH is generally regarded as an acid gas [9]. Based on the aforementioned background, a series of rare-earth metals (Nd, Er and Y) with different ionic radii modified HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts were prepared and used for CH3SH decomposition test in the present study. The effects of modification of rare earth metals on the physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalysts were investigated. In addition, several characterization studies, including XRD, XRF, FT-IR, 27Al-NMR, UV–vis, BET, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD and Raman, were carried out to provide valuable information to understand the reason for the improved catalytic activity and stability of the modified HZSM-5 zeolite. Furthermore, deactivation and regeneration of the spent catalysts were also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The commercial HZSM-5 catalyst (Si/Al ratio was 20) was obtained from Fuxu zeolite company, China. Pure catalyst was calcined at 550°C for 5h to remove impurities. The modification of rare earth metals (Nd, Er and Y) was accomplished by conventional incipient wetness impregnation method, and detail impregnation process is recorded as follows: 5g of pure HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst was modified with a certain amount of RE(NO3)3·6H2O (RE=Nd, Er and Y) in aqueous solution at room temperature for 12h, to obtain RE/HZSM-5 catalysts with 5wt% l loading of RE. Meanwhile, the neodymium (Nd) nitrate aqueous solutions with certain concentrations were used to prepare Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst with 1, 5, 9, 13 and 17wt% loading of Nd. The impregnated powder was dried at 80°C for 6h and then calcined in air at 550°C for 5h. Preparation details are recorded in Electronic Supplementary Material and the content of rare earth metal in the modified zeolite catalyst was calculated by the formula described in previous research [22]. 2.2 Catalysts characterization N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 instrument. Before the measurement, all the samples were degassed under vacuum at 250°C for 4h. Specific total surface area and microporous volume of the synthesized samples were calculated from BET method and t-plot method, respectively. XRD patterns were recorded by a Rigaku D/max-1200 diffractometer, using Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) as an X-ray source and operating at 40kV and 30mA. FT-IR experiments were performed on a Nicolet 560 IR spectrometer with standard KBr pellet method. XRF were used to analyze the chemical composition of the synthesized catalysts. The 27Al NMR experiments were conducted on a Bruker Avance III 600 spectrometer at a resonance frequency of 156.4MHz and the spectra were collected at a spinning rate of 12KHz. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Cary 500 spectrometer with an integration sphere diffuse reflectance attachment. Raman tests were operated at room temperature to analyze the nature of coke deposited on the catalyst after reaction, using a Via Reflex Raman spectrometer with 514nm emission lines from Ar+ laser. NH3-TPD experiments were performed on an instrument equipped with a TCD detector. About 0.2g of the catalyst was dried at 500°C for 2h in He flow and then cooled down to 100°C. NH3 adsorption was conducted at 100°C for 2h by flowing 10% NH3/He under a flow rate of 30ml/min to saturate the acid sites of the catalyst. Then the sample was purged with He flow at 100°C for 1h to desorb the weakly or physically adsorbed NH3 from the catalyst surface. Finally, TPD was carried out in 30ml/min He flow, ramping the temperature from 100°C to 700°C at a ramp rate of 10°C/min. The desorbed NH3 was detected by the TCD detector. CO2-TPD tests were measured at the same apparatus for NH3-TPD. About 0.2g of the sample was pretreated in He flow at 600°C for 2h, then cooled to 30°C and adsorbed by CO2 (10% CO2/He) at 30°C for 2h. The catalyst was flushed with He flow for 1h, and CO2 desorption was recorded from 30°C to 600°C with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. 2.3 Catalytic tests A fixed-bed micro-reactor was used for catalytic decomposition of CH3SH at atmospheric pressure from 350°C to 600°C. An amount of 0.2g of catalyst with particle size of 0.25–0.42mm (60–40mesh) diluted with 0.2g of quartz sand was loaded into the reactor. Then, a gas mixture of 1vol% CH3SH in N2 was supplied as feed gas, and the flow rate of the feed gas was 30ml/min. The stability tests of pure HZSM-5 sample and 13% Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst were performed at 500°C. The gaseous products were analyzed by two online gas chromatograph (GC), equipped with two TCD detectors, one FPD detector and one FID detector. The concentration of CH3SH was detected by the FID and FPD detectors, and the concentrations of CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and other hydrocarbons were analyzed by the FID detector. Meanwhile, two TCD detectors were used to quantitate the concentrations of produced H2, CO and CO2. The conversion of CH3SH (%) was defined by the under-mentioned equation: C o n v e r s i o n o f C H 3 S H ( % ) = C [ C H 3 S H ] i n − C [ C H 3 S H ] o u t C [ C H 3 S H ] i n × 100 where C[CH3SH]in is the content of CH3SH in the feedstock, and C[CH3SH]out is the content of CH3SH in the product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of rare-earth (Nd, Er and Y) modification 3.1.1 Characterization results of the synthesized catalysts Fig. 1 exhibits the XRD patterns of pure HZSM-5 and RE metals (Nd, Er and Y) modified HZSM-5 catalysts. It is clear the XRD patterns of all these samples are similar, and no peaks associated with the doped RE oxides are observed in the patterns of Nd, Er and Y doped HZSM-5 catalysts. This suggests that modification of RE metals does not destroy the lattice structure of the HZSM-5 zeolite, and the formed RE oxides are well dispersed on the synthesized samples [17,23]. Moreover, SEM and element mapping characterization of the 17wt%Nd-ZSM-5 is given in Electronic Supplementary Material (as shown in Fig. S1) to further prove the dispersing of Nd metals. When compared with the pure HZSM-5 sample, however, RE metals modified HZSM-5 catalysts present lower peak intensity. One possibility for the lower intensity of the XRD patterns from the RE impregnated HZSM-5 is that the high atomic weight rare earths absorb X-rays. Meanwhile, one other possibility for the decrease of peak intensity could either be originated from the existence of RE species that are incorporated into the channels of the prepared catalysts [24]. or resulted from the framework defects caused by partial dealumination of HZSM-5 [25,26]. The textural properties and FT-IR characterization of the HZSM-5 and RE-doped HZEM-5 catalysts are recorded in Table 1 , Figs. S2 and Fig. S3, respectively (as shown in the Electronic Supplementary Material). Fig. 2 illustrates the NH3-TPD profiles of the pure HZSM-5 and RE (Nd, Er and Y) doped HZSM-5 samples. The TPD profile of the pure HZSM-5 consists of two major desorption peaks at about 250°C and 500°C, representing for weak acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively [13,26]. As demonstrated in Fig. 2, after modification of rare earth metals, the low-temperature desorption peaks exhibit small changes in intensity, suggesting that the strength of weak acidity is not evidently affected. However, the amount of the strong acid sites is significantly eliminated by RE species addition according to the markedly decrease of the intensity of the high-temperature desorption peaks. It was reported that the Al in zeolitic framework was generally contributed to the strong acid sites [27]. Hence, the loss of the strong acid sites could be ascribed to the dealumination in the framework of HZSM-5, which was suggested in the literature reported previously [19] and also revealed by the characterization results of the XRD, 27Al NMR and UV–vis (as shown in Figs. S4 and S5 in Electronic Supplementary Material). More importantly, the decrease in the concentration of strong acidity may result in more stable of the active sites of the catalyst and a better anti-coking capability during the reaction [28], which should be responsible for the increased catalytic activity and stability. Fig. 3 presents the CO2-TPD analysis of the pure and rare earth metals modified HZSM-5 catalysts. From Fig. 3, a desorption peak at the temperature of 120°C is seen for the unmodified sample, and this peak was reported to indicate the presence of surface basic sites that was due to the interaction between the framework of HZSM-5 and CO2 [29]. It is apparent that the intensity of CO2 desorption peaks increase after impregnation of rare earth elements, implying the formation of increased amount of surface basic sites. Moreover, modification of Nd causes a larger increase in peak intensity, meaning that Nd introduction demonstrates a remarkable effect on the enhanced basicity of the catalyst. It is generally accepted that modification of rare earth metals could effectively tune the acid-base property of the HZSM-5 catalyst, since rare earth oxides usually present some basic characters. Moreover, Nd with larger cation radius (Er3+ =1.00Å, Y=1.015Å and Nd=1.12Å [30,31]) could associate more ligand number of oxygen, thus contributing to increased amount of basic sites [32]. Due to high acidity of CH3SH [9], it could be easily adsorbed by the basic sites on the catalyst. Therefore, RE modified HZSM-5 catalysts with increased alkalinity would display better adsorption ability to CH3SH, which should contribute to the enhanced catalytic activity. 3.1.2 Catalytic activity of the catalysts The evaluation results of catalytic activity tests for decomposition of CH3SH over pure HZSM-5 and RE modified HZSM-5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . As the reaction temperature rose up, the CH3SH conversion over all the catalysts increase. It should be noted that from 400 to 450°C, the CH3SH conversion displays a slight decrease over the pure HZSM-5 catalyst, which merely attributes to the equilibrium conversion as explained in the previous study [13]. From Fig. 4, catalytic activity for CH3SH decomposition (in terms of CH3SH conversion) over rare earth elements modified HZSM-5 catalysts is much higher than that over pure HZSM-5 zeolite sample. The conversion of CH3SH is completed over the modified HZSM-5 catalysts at 500°C, the CH3SH conversion over the pure HZSM-5 catalyst, by contrast, is about 80% at this time. When the reaction temperature increases to 550°C, the CH3SH conversion of the RE modified HZSM-5 catalyst samples reaches up to 100%, but slightly amount of CH3SH in the outlet gas still can be detected from the pure HZSM-5 catalyst sample. Therefore, it is obvious that the addition of rare earth metals significantly enhances the activity of the catalyst. Furthermore, it is found that the activity of Nd/HZSM-5 is higher than that of Er and Y doped HZSM-5 catalysts when the reaction temperature is 450°C. According to the characterization results, after impregnation of rare earth metals, on the one hand, increased amount of basic sites are presented on the doped-HZSM-5 samples. Furthermore, the introduction of Nd causes a remarkable effect on the enhanced basicity of the catalyst. On the other hand, the decrease in the concentration of strong acidity may result in more stable of the active sites of the modified HZSM-5 catalysts. All these should be responsible for the increased catalytic activity of the RE modified catalysts, especially for Nd/HZSM-5 sample. 3.2 Effect of neodymium (Nd) content 3.2.1 Characterization results of the catalysts Since Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst has been proven to be very efficient among all the RE (Nd, Er and Y) modified HZSM-5 catalysts. Hence, the effect of Nd content (with 1, 5, 9, 13 and 17wt% loading amount of Nd) on the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and their catalytic performance for CH3SH decomposition are detailed investigated. Fig. 5 illustrates the XRD patterns of the pure HZSM-5 and Nd/HZSM-5 catalysts with different Nd contents. All catalysts exhibit the similarity of the XRD patterns, indicating that the original structure of HZSM-5 is well retained after Nd modification. Nevertheless, the XRD intensities of the Nd modified HZSM-5 catalysts are relatively lower than that of the unmodified one and the peak intensity gradually decreases with increasing Nd content. As explained before, the decrease of the peak intensity in the modified catalysts was either resulted from the existence of RE species inside the channel of HZSM-5 or attributed to the framework defects caused by dealumination [25,26]. Therefore, the XRD results displayed here also indicate the entrance of Nd species into the channels or partial dealumination of the HZSM-5 during the process of impregnation of Nd. NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD profiles of the pure HZSM-5 and Nd/HZSM5 with different Nd contents are displayed in Figs. 6 and 7 , respectively. It is clear that the acidic-basic properties of the catalysts are strongly influenced by the Nd content. On the one hand, as the content of Nd increase, the amount of the strong acid sites (high-temperature desorption peak) decrease sharply. When the content of Nd reaches to 13% or even higher, the peak ascribed to the strong acid sites can hardly be observed. In particular, quantitative results of NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD are listed in Table S1 (as shown in Electronic Supplementary Material). Considering the results of the XRD, 27Al NMR and UV–vis, and also combining the results discussed previously, the loss of the strong acid sites could be corresponded to the partial dealumination in the framework of HZSM-5. The reduced amounts of strong acid sites may be favorable for the better catalytic performance in decomposition of CH3SH. On the other hand, with increasing Nd loading from 1% to 13%, the intensity of the CO2 desorption peak increase. When Nd loading increases to 17%, the intensity of the CO2 desorption peak remains unchanged. Therefore, the appropriate amount of Nd in the Nd/HZSM5 catalysts would lead to the formation of increased amount of surface basic sites, which is responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity. 3.2.2 Catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts Fig. 8 compares the activity for CH3SH catalytic decomposition over the pure HZSM-5 and Nd/HZSM-5 catalysts as a function of temperature. It is seen from Fig. 8 that the activities of these samples differ sharply. The addition of Nd to HZSM-5 catalysts displays a considerable improvement in terms of CH3SH conversion. Moreover, an increasing Nd content is found to positively affect the catalytic activity as suggested by higher CH3SH conversion. The highest conversion of CH3SH is obtained over the 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst. But further Nd addition (with Nd loading increases to 17%) leads to a slightly decrease of CH3SH conversion. As mentioned, introduction of Nd into HZSM-5 catalysts was believed not only to adjust the formation of increased amount of surface basic sites in its favor, but also to decrease the amount of the strong acid sites. CH3SH could be easily adsorbed by the basic sites because of its high acidity and this would contribute to the increased catalytic activity. Furthermore, the decrease in the concentration of the strong acidity may result in more stable of the active sites of the catalyst, which could be responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity as well. Therefore, rare earth Nd has a rather important role in tuning the acid-base properties of the HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst, which results in an increased catalytic activity in CH3SH decomposition. But too much addition of Nd (more than 17% Nd loading) does not further increase the reactivity, since too many Nd species that are entered into the channels of HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst, to some extent, may slightly affect the structural and surface properties of the catalyst. These results demonstrate that it is necessary to have a suitable amount of Nd (with l3wt% load of Nd) in the process of catalyst synthesis. The primary tests have indicated that 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity. Hence, the stability tests of the pure HZSM-5 and 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalysts are evaluated at 500°C, and the test results are shown in Fig. 9 . The parent HZSM-5 catalyst exhibits a poor stability in catalytic decomposition of CH3SH. It is faced with deactivation after a relatively short time on-stream reaction (about 15h), and the conversion of CH3SH decreases from 98% to 50% after 30h of exposure. In contrast, 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 shows high stability with no obvious deactivation during the 60h test, indicating that the addition of Nd markedly improve the stability of the HZSM-5 catalyst. The improved stability of the 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst could be interpreted by the fact that modification of Nd into HZSM-5 catalyst could restrict the accumulation of coke deposit, since the amount of the strong acid sites which is closely related to the formation of coke deposit is significantly eliminated on this catalyst. 3.3 Possible reaction mechanism for the conversion of CH3SH over HZSM-5 based catalysts It is well known that the accumulation of coke deposit on zeolite catalyst was considered as the main reason for the deactivation of the catalyst in CH3SH decomposition process [13] and Raman spectroscopy was generally used to evaluate the nature of coke deposit over the spent catalyst [33,34]. Therefore, characterization of the coke deposit on the fresh and spent samples is conducted by Raman technique in the present study, and the corresponding result is depicted in Fig. 10 . It can be observed that several Raman bands at about 1180, 1380–1500, and 1610cm−1 are presented in the spectra of the spent catalysts, which are absent in that of the fresh HZSM-5 and Nd/HZSM-5 catalysts. These signals obviously indicate that coke is deposited over the spent catalysts, and this coke deposit is possibly originated from the deep dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons during the reaction [33], since hydrocarbons (such as CH4, C2H4, C2H6, etc.) are indicated as the main products during the process of CH3SH decomposition [13]. As shown in Fig. 9, after 40h on stream, the CH3SH conversion over the pure HZSM-5 catalyst reduces to 0% approximately. Fig. 10 exhibits that a large amount of coke is deposited at this time. Hence, the accumulated coke deposit could finally lead to a decrease in CH3SH conversion, because it could either poison the active sites or block the access to them by the reactant molecules [35]. In contrast, the CH3SH conversion over the 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst does not decrease after 40h of exposure though coke is already formed at this time. This is because that the amount of the coke deposit over the 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst is much lower than that over the pure HZSM-5 catalyst after the same exposure time (40h) of the reaction. Therefore, it is accepted that a large number of active sites are still possessed at this moment, which will be further proved by the result in Fig. 11 . Moreover, from Fig. 10, the amount of the coke over the 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst increases with increasing the exposure time from 0 to 80h. But to our surprise, the intensity represented for the coke deposit of 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst with 80h of exposure is still lower than that of pure HZSM-5 catalyst with 40h of exposure. This suggests that the 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst possesses stronger resistance to the formation of coke deposit during the reaction. As mentioned before, the decrease in the concentration of the strong acid sites over the RE modified HZSM-5 catalyst could effectively suppress the formation of coke on the zeolite catalyst surface. Although the strong acid sites can promote the formation of coke deposit, it has been reported that the acid sites on HZSM-5 catalyst could generally be regarded as the active sites/active centres in CH3SH catalytic decomposition [13,14]. Hence, a comparison of the NH3-TPD data of the fresh and spent samples is investigated and the results are depicted in Fig. 11. Apparently, the pure HZSM-5 catalyst lose most of its acid sites after 40h of exposure, and its CH3SH conversion almost decreases to 0% as obtained from Fig. 9. Whereas in 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst, a certain amount of weak acid sites can be found, even after 80h on stream. As expected, nearly 60% of CH3SH conversion is displayed at this time (Fig. 9). For the pure HZSM-5 catalyst, the acid sites may be completely covered due to the serious accumulation of coke deposit after 40h of exposure. But for the 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst, the decrease in the amount of strong acid sites that could effectively result in the decrease of coke amount may give rise to less coverage of the weak acid sites during the reaction. The existence of the weak acid sites could provide enough active centres for CH3SH decomposition. On the basis of the above results, a possible reaction mechanism for the conversion of CH3SH over the pure and modified HZSM-5 catalysts is proposed, and the results are illustrated in Scheme 1 . CH3SH, due to its strong acidity, could be firstly absorbed by the basic sites on the HZSM-5 catalyst. Then, the absorbed CH3SH molecules would be migrated to the active centres. Finally, CH3SH would be ultimately converted into the corresponding products (such as CH4 and other hydrocarbons) that have been reported in previous researches [13–15] (CH4 production as a function of time in the present study is also shown in Fig. S6 in Electronic Supplementary Material). However, the produced hydrocarbons would be dehydrogenated deeply on the strong acid sites over the HZSM-5 catalyst, and this would lead to form a lot of coke deposit during the reaction. The accumulated coke deposit could either poison the active centres or block the access to them by the CH3SH molecules, and finally causes the decrease of catalytic activity. For RE doped HZSM-5 catalyst (13wt%Nd/HZSM-5), after modification of Nd, increased amount of surface basic sites are formed. Moreover, the amount of the strong acid sites is obviously decreased. The increased amount of surface basic sites could lead to more CH3SH molecules are adsorbed, and the decrease of the strong acidity may result in more stable of the active sites of the catalyst. All these should be responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity. More importantly, the decrease in the amount of the strong acid sites could suppress the formation of coke deposit, which may cause less coverage of the weak acid sites during the reaction, and the existence of the weak acid sites could provide enough active centres for CH3SH decomposition. Therefore, the catalytic stability of the 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst has significantly been improved. 3.4 Regeneration of spent catalysts Regeneration of the used 13wt%Nd-modified HZSM-5 catalyst is carried out by switching 30ml/min air flow at 500°C (the temperature is the same as the reaction temperature) for 30min, and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . Surprisingly, it is found that the used catalyst can be well recovered to its original performance after regeneration. Furthermore, multi-cycle regeneration performance (4 regeneration cycles) has also been conducted (results are not shown), and the results illustrate that the used catalyst can be well regenerated for many times, which highlights its industrial application. The acidity and alkalinity properties of the regenerated catalysts are also well recovered after the regeneration process (as presented in Fig. S8A and 8B in Electronic Supplementary Material). 3.5 Catalytic performance comparison of Nd/HZSM-5 with other reported catalysts The catalytic activity and stability obtained by using Nd/HZSM-5 as catalysts is compared with that of other reported catalysts. Detail results are collected and presented in Table 2 . It is found that catalytic performance of pure HZSM-5 in the present work is comparable to that of HZSM-5 catalyst reported previously [13,14]. CH3SH can be completely decomposed over pure HZSM-5 zeolite above 550°C, and this pure zeolite catalyst faces with deactivation after a relatively short time on-stream reaction (about 12–15h). Furthermore, it is noted that other popular catalysts (ceria based catalysts) also confront with low catalytic stability during CH3SH decomposition processes [10–12,36], and these catalysts will deactivate after about 10h test. Nd modified HZSM-5 catalysts, by contrast, can obtain 100% CH3SH conversion at 500°C. Moreover, the modified HZSM-5 catalyst shows high stability with no obvious deactivation during the 60h test. Therefore, the improvements for the modified HZM-5 catalysts investigated in the present study can be observed obviously. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of rare earth metals (Nd, Er and Y) modified HZSM-5 catalysts and pure HZSM-5 catalyst was prepared and tested for catalytic decomposition of CH3SH. The catalysis tests showed that rare earth metals (especially for Nd) modification increased both catalytic activity and catalytic stability. Based on the characterization results, increased amount of basic sites were presented on the modified HZSM-5 catalysts. Moreover, the decrease of the strong acid sites amount over the RE modified HZSM-5 catalysts resulted in more stable of the active sites of the catalysts and also suppressed the formation of coke on the catalysts surface. All these features gave rise to the increased catalytic activity and catalytic stability. The optimal Nd content was detailed investigated and 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst showed high stability with no obvious deactivation during the 60h test. In addition, the spent catalysts can be successfully regenerated with air for many times. coredata.dc:description: A series of HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts modified with various rare earth metals (Nd, Er and Y) was prepared and used for CH3SH catalytic decomposition test. The results revealed that addition of rare earth metals significantly improved activity and stability of the HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts, and Nd-modified catalyst exhibited the best performance. Several characterization studies were undertaken to correlate structural and surface properties of the obtained catalysts with their catalytic performance. It was found that acid-base properties of the catalysts were closely related to the catalytic performance. The NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analysis showed that the concentration of strong acid sites of the HZSM-5 catalysts decreased after rare earth metals addition, while the concentration of basic sites of the catalysts increased. The decrease in the amount of strong acid sites suppressed the formation of coke on the catalysts. The catalysts with increased amount of basic sites displayed better adsorption ability to CH3SH. The UV–vis, 27Al NMR and XRD analysis indicated that the existence of an empty f orbit Nd3+ caused the increase of non-framework aluminium species amount, which leaded to the decrease of the strong acid sites amount. In addition, the optimal loading amount of Nd was investigated and 13wt%Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst showed no obvious deactivation during 60h test. The spent Nd/HZSM-5 catalyst can be successfully regenerated, showing that Nd/HZSM-5 was an efficient catalyst for CH3SH elimination.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of rare-earth (Nd, Er and Y) doping on catalytic performance of HZSM-5 zeolite catalysts for methyl mercaptan (CH3SH) decomposition
